title: OS Level 5 â€” I/O Systems & Device Management
concept: I/O hardware, device drivers, interrupts, polling, DMA and buffering.

questions.question: Which component typically acts as the software interface between device controller and OS?
questions.explanation: Device drivers hide device specifics and provide a standard interface to the OS.

questions.question: Compared to polling, interrupts are generally preferred because they:

options.B: Reduce CPU time wasted waiting for I/O

questions.explanation: Interrupts notify CPU only when needed, reducing busy waiting.

questions.question: DMA (Direct Memory Access) is used to:

options.A: Allow devices to transfer data directly to/from memory without CPU for each byte

questions.explanation: DMA controllers handle bulk data transfer, freeing CPU from byte-by-byte I/O.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a block device?
questions.explanation: Block devices support random access in fixed-size blocks (disk, SSD).

questions.question: Which is typically a character device?
questions.explanation: Character devices (e.g., terminals, serial ports) are accessed as streams of characters.

questions.question: Double buffering in I/O is used to:

options.B: Overlap I/O and computation, improving throughput

questions.explanation: Double buffering allows one buffer to be filled while another is processed.

questions.question: Spooling (Simultaneous Peripheral Operation On-Line) is commonly used with:
questions.explanation: Print jobs are spooled to disk before being sent to printers sequentially.

questions.question: Which statement about device independence is TRUE?

options.A: Applications must know exact device details
options.B: OS provides a common interface so apps need not care about device specifics
options.C: It applies only to network devices
options.D: It prevents new devices from being added

questions.explanation: Device independence lets the same I/O calls work for different devices.

questions.question: Which of these is a valid reason to use caching at the I/O subsystem?

options.B: Reduce average access time by keeping frequently used data in memory
options.D: Force all writes directly to disk without buffering

questions.explanation: I/O caching improves performance by avoiding repeated slow device accesses.

questions.question: Which of the following is an I/O scheduling goal?

options.B: Minimize response time and maximize throughput

questions.explanation: I/O scheduling aims to reduce latency and increase throughput fairly.
